section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to introduce the book and identify it as an informational text about weather.
Use Circle Time to introduce the vocabulary word (peek).
Use Circle Time to introduce the letters Mm and Nn.
Begin story time by introducing the Big Book and asking, What kind of weather did you learn about?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Participate in prereading and reading-related activities.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in text.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Read-Aloud Comprehension: Use information to categorize. Relate own experiences to those in books.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Use regular and irregular plurals.
Share observations about events.
Understand and use a growing number of theme words.
Describe what happens when the earth or the sky changes.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Teach the letters Mm and Nn.
Read-aloud My Mess and In Nature.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What type of weather do you see in your book?
Can you pretend to be a weather person? What is the weather today?
Look out the window. What would you tell a friend about the weather today?
Can you write about what you like to do on rainy days?
What can you make to keep you dry in the rain?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word mitten? Can you write it?
Can you use the blocks to build a tall weather tower? What can you see from the top of the tower?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder be curious, and introduce vocabulary (ask questions, explain).
Start Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Weather.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Participate in prereading and reading-related activities.
Join two or more words to create a compound word.
Understand conventions of print including end punctuation and case.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Read-Aloud Comprehension: Use information to describe. Use information to categorize. Relate own experiments to those in books.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Describe what happens when the earth or the sky changes.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe where light, heat, and electricity come from.
Use technology, including learning applications, to express own ideas.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children access their curiosity.
Show children the basic steps of an experiment and allow children to make predictions and observations.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you show me your favorite kind of weather in a book?
Can you pretend to be a windstorm?
Can you explain how rain falls?
What question about the weather can you write? Can you make a question mark at the end?
Can you make a rainbow? Can you show all the colors?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word night? Can you write it?
Can you build something to keep people safe and dry during a thunderstorm?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to discuss basic needs related to weather and teach vocabulary (float).
Start Story Time by revisiting Weather and asking the guiding question: How does weather help us?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Join two or more words to create a compound word; Blend two or more syllables to create a word.
Use information to categorize.
Write for different purposes.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Describe what happens when the earth or the sky changes.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe where light, heat, and electricity come from.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Economics: Show understanding that people have basic needs, e.g., food, clothing, and shelter.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Review with children that there are different kinds of clouds and they can tell us something about the weather.
Guide children to expand science vocabulary.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How many question marks can you find in your book? How many periods?
Can you pretend to be in a snowstorm? How would you walk on a very windy day?
Can you draw a rainbow? How many colors did you use?
Can you write about the three kinds of clouds?
Can you make a cloud with the materials?
Can you find the letter at the beginning of the word milk in the Magnetic Letters?
Can you build a snow fort by using blocks?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Weather by Kristin Baird Rattini. Copyright © 2013 by National Geographic Partners LLC. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with National Geographic Partners LLC.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photos © Shutterstock: cotton balls (STILLFX), feathers (Potapov Alexander), paint (Antonsov85), paper (jannoon028).

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: What’s the Weather?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about weather. Introduce vocabulary (snowy, windy).
Start Story Time by connecting the texts Weather and What’s the Weather?
Read interactively and connect to the Concept Question: How can weather affect us?
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Compare and contrast two stories relating to the same topic.
Understand conventions of print, including end punctuation and case.
Compose an informative text; Share and celebrate written products; Use top to bottom and left to right directionality when writing.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Engage in conflict resolution.
Describe what happens when the earth or the sky changes.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Economics: Show understanding that people have basic needs, e.g., food, clothing, and shelter.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Review the Big Chart of Big Ideas.
Guide children as they create a book about weather.
Encourage children to work as a team.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find labels in your book?
Can you think about and put on the clothes you should wear for a snowy day?
How many sunny-day activities can you think of? Take a Counter for each activity you name. How many counters did you get?
Can you write about the weather you like best?
Can you create something that sounds like a rainstorm?
Find the letter at the beginning of the word nut in the Magnetic Letters.
Can you build a kite? Can you build an umbrella?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Weather by Kristin Baird Rattini. Copyright © 2013 by National Geographic Partners LLC. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with National Geographic Partners LLC.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photos © Shutterstock: crayons (Svitlana Kataieva), markers (nikkytok), paper (jannoon028).

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to actively engage children and introduce vocabulary (freeze).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking the guiding question: How can you plan for the weather?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and enjoyment.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Participate in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Use information to describe; Use information to compare and contrast; Relate own experiences to those in books.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Writing: Compose an informative text.; Share and celebrate written products.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Share observations about events.
Use regular and irregular plurals.
Describe what happens when the earth or the sky changes.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Economics: Show understanding that people have basic needs, e.g. food, clothing, and shelter.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: If you could control the weather, what kind of weather would you make?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you wrote a story about weather, what would it be?
Can you pretend to be rain? Snow? Hail? Sun? Wind? Lightning and thunder?
Can you imagine a lot of snow? Show how tall the snow is using Connecting Cubes.
Can you write a story about wild weather?
Can you invent a weather machine? What materials will you use?
How many Mm’s and Nn’s can you find around the room?
Can you build a shelter that goes with your favorite kind of weather?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Weather by Kristin Baird Rattini. Copyright © 2013 by National Geographic Partners LLC. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with National Geographic Partners LLC.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Engage in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Recognize at least 20 distinct letter sounds in the language of instruction.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Observe and describe what happens during changes in the earth and sky.
Identify some conventional features of print that communicate meaning, including end punctuation and case.
Engage in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Combine words to make a compound word.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Observe and describe what happens during changes in the earth and sky.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss sources of energy.
Use digital learning applications and programs to create digital products and express own ideas.
Combine words to make a compound word.
Blend syllables into words.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Observe and describe what happens during changes in the earth and sky.
Demonstrate that all people need food, clothing, and shelter.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Share and celebrate written products.
Can identify some conventional features of print that communicate meaning, including end punctuation and case.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Observe and describe what happens during changes in the earth and sky.
Engage in pre-reading and reading-related activities.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Share and celebrate class-made and individual written products.
Use appropriate directionality when writing (top to bottom, left to right).
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Observe and describe what happens during changes in the earth and sky.
